medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began by age 3 years with severe visual handicap and photophobia. Fundus examination showed a bullâ€™s eye macular lesion at age 5, with questionable pallor of the optic disc. At age 9, the patient began having seizures and was diagnosed with juvenile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (JNCL). By the time of death, the patient was reported to have no visual function.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Juvenile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (JNCL); diagnosed and formally noted at age 9, with a significant history of progressive neurodegeneration.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's older sister was diagnosed with JNCL at age 9 and became blind by age 16, currently 24 years old with epilepsy but retains some cognitive ability.
